item.title: Create AI images with Google‚Äôs Gemini model
item.description:
Ethan Mollick on LinkedIn: I think that Google may have come out of nowhere to have the best LLM‚Ä¶ | 19 comments

ImageFX Is the tool to generate images with Google‚Äôs Gemini. I‚Äôve been a huge fan of using ChatGPT on iOS to get images for this blog. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually good or not. But it‚Äôs helped me associate a post with an idea (image), which I think is incredibly helpful for memory retention. So my theory has been: some content is better than no content. The other thought is: better learn now what these tools are and how to use them because you never know where you‚Äôre going to be able to take them. They‚Äôre like learning how to drive a car: if you can drive, you can go places.

So how does ImageFX compare? Here‚Äôs the prompt:

a battle of chatgpt vs Google Gemini photo generators. Psychedelic. Parasitic. Enlightened. Groovy. Ethereal. Down to earth.

Google:

And ChatGPT:

This is but one test, and clearly chatGPT wins.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: Protobufs - Everything I don‚Äôt know
item.description:
If you want a guide on Protobufs this isn‚Äôt it. These are my notes. Just stumbled on this tonight after having seen these all over the place at Google and I wanted to learn something.

See Protocol Buffers Documentation and ChatGPT. Pkl for Configuration Management made me think of this. # The point of a Protobuf

  • write one file
  • This file defines data structure, but not the data itself
  • Compile it to different languages (like Python)
  • A file in Python will be have a class defined with the properties in it
  • When you serialize data (send via JSON or something over an API) the other service knows how to read that data file immediately (if you built it and gave it the proto)
    • This makes sense to me why Google used this everywhere. They have one service in Python and another in Java and another in Go. To get them talking to each other they need a common data structure to read from.
    • The setters and getters help with the parsing a JSON blob for example.

Like first you define the protobuf

And then you compile it via a bash command and it turns to this:

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: Pkl for Configuration Management
item.description:
Pkl is the new kid on the block.

Have you ever built a config for a modeling pipeline? Surely, if you‚Äôve built a pipeline to do experiments you‚Äôve wondered how you can quickly iterate through a bunch of different settings to see which model is the best for your use case.

Maybe you want to generate a list of hypothesis to test, and then compare and contrast them.

Like any good data scientist you‚Äôve created a system to loop over some settings.

It‚Äôs the big challenge of data science: how do I configure something? Should I build this function to do one thing or should I build a development environment where I can explore a thousand things? If I build a development environment how do I know if all the things I‚Äôve configured aren‚Äôt going to be moot in a few weeks or months?

I don‚Äôt have the answer to those questions. But perhaps how we design our configs can affect those design decisions.

Pkl is cool because it lets you do a for loop to output configs.

Here‚Äôs a basic config file per their docs:

And here‚Äôs that config looped and rendered:

Application to DS

I‚Äôm not 100% sure that this is any easier for a Python developer than just using ChatGPT to loop some parameters and spit out a bunch of yaml files. Because YAML does have some validation to it. And YAML has been around a long time.

Anything‚Äôs better than Python‚Äôs ConfigParser‚Ä¶yuck.

Reminds me of Protocol Buffers Documentation but honestly I don‚Äôt know much about this stuff. See Protobufs - Everything I don‚Äôt know

But it‚Äôs nice to see people are thinking about configs‚Ä¶

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: Galileo AI
item.description:
I came across Galileo AI. It lets you mock up UI interfaces. Great story in their blog: Galileo AI - Feb 6 Launch Announcement

It doesn‚Äôt export the code itself, but for a fee it‚Äôll export to Figma for you. The cool thing is they trained or fine tuned an LLM specifically on design components. This is a cool use case of how people with specialized skill sets will create custom LLMs to compete in areas ChatGPT won‚Äôt be able to.

This is also showing the emergence in new software: don‚Äôt build a rules engine, train an LLM to solve the problem.

_________________________

item.title: How to share an HTML file (like a quarto output in GitHub)
item.description:
Let‚Äôs assume you have a raw HTML file on GitHub, such as a Jupyter notebook you rendered to HTML or a Quarto doc you rendered via quarto render.

If you try to share the link from GitHub directly, GitHub will just show the raw HTML file.

Use this link to convert it to your dashboard:

GitHub & BitBucket HTML Preview

Example:

GitHub File: https://github.com/bryanwhiting/blog/blob/gh-pages/index.html

Preview using that link: https://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/bryanwhiting/blog/blob/gh-pages/index.html

Notice the URL at the bottom is not my site or my GitHub path.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: Embedding audio in Quarto
item.description:
I want to embed just a plain audio file in my blog post.

Check out the post Guitar: Clouds, where I embed some audio using the quarto video short link: Quarto ‚Äì Videos.

My process:

  • take a voice recording with my voice notes on iOS.
  • Save to files, I did audio/ folder (How to blog from your phone using quarto (or hugo/jekyll/etc) using Working Copy and Obsidian)
  • Then if I link using a standard markdown link it‚Äôll create an audio recording in a new browser. If I use the video shortcode then quarto will embed it as a video right in the post (doesn‚Äôt open a new browser). You can adjust the height so it‚Äôs not a massive black screen.

Song snippet today: [2024-02-05-guitar-clouds](../audio/2024-02-05-guitar-clouds.m4a) 3rd capo, G, Em, C, G with some pinky action. 


<-- This works on safari, not chrome desktop for some reason --> 

![2024-02-05-guitar-clouds](../audio/2024-02-05-guitar-clouds.m4a)

Hope this helps someone!

Note, the second way (the ![]) approach didn‚Äôt work on Chrome Desktop, but works on Safari desktop, safari mobile, and chrome mobile:

If I inspect the HTML I can see the audio tag is created in Chrome, it‚Äôs just not showing a player or anything.

But the mobile audio player is picked up:

Obsidian

I like using this markdown syntax in Obsidian because that‚Äôs where I write my notes.

Because it appears like an audio player in app. The syntax is a quarto thing and renders nicely. The <audio> tag is supposed to work but doesn‚Äôt in my vault. In my app it looks like this;

So yes, the markdown link is the most usable, works on most browsers, and works in Obsidian. Just doesn‚Äôt work on Chrome Web‚Ä¶(at least not on my version).

Seems also that using the <audio> tag breaks my quarto:

In Summary

I‚Äôve found two ways of showing audio in quarto. 1) using the image syntax in markdown and 2) using a video shortcode. The markdown syntax works great locally on my iPhone and on most browsers, but the video shortcode seems to work on all browsers.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: The Divinely Discontent Chatbot User
item.description:
There is Divine Discontent in the Consumer Appetite

Jeff Bezos alluded to the ‚Äúdivinely discontent‚Äù customer in a 2017 shareholder letter (Elements of Amazon‚Äôs Day 1 Culture | AWS Executive Insights).

One thing I love about customers is that they are divinely discontent. Their expectations are never static ‚Äì they go up. It‚Äôs human nature. We didn‚Äôt ascend from our hunter-gatherer days by being satisfied. People have a voracious appetite for a better way, and yesterday‚Äôs ‚Äòwow‚Äô quickly becomes today‚Äôs ‚Äòordinary‚Äô. I see that cycle of improvement happening at a faster rate than ever before 2017 Amazon_Shareholder_Letter.pdf

More googling shows the phrase was also used by Neal A Maxwell in 1976 (Notwithstanding My Weakness):

What can we do to manage these vexing feelings of inadequacy? Here are but a few suggestions: (1) We can distinguish more clearly between divine discontent and the devil‚Äôs dissonance, between dissatisfaction with self and disdain for self. We need the first and must shun the second, remembering that when conscience calls to us from the next ridge, it is not solely to scold but also to beckon.

(Just dropping that in case Bezos gets all the credit for the term üòâ.)

LLM Discontent

People grappling with building LLMs are facing this discontent at an alarming rate. The LLM Chatbot Arena Leaderboard is a testament to how quickly appetites will change. Many AI tool providers refrain from vendor lock in and try to build LLM agnostic tooling.

How do you compete? Well, most of us aren‚Äôt building these foundational models. How do they compete with each other? None of us care. We just want a good one.

But ask yourself, would you rather have Bard from today or nothing from 2022?

These leaderboards are fascinating because in 14 months since ChatGPT emerged we‚Äôve become so reliant on these tools but yet they‚Äôre not even old enough to walk or talk by human standards. Yet we now have Bard, ChatGPT, LLaMA, Mistral, Claude, and whatever‚Äôs cooking at Amazon/Apple/Microsoft (behind the scenes as a contingency plan I‚Äôm sure) and the Chinese/Indian companies that don‚Äôt want to rely on the U.S.

It‚Äôs the early days of search: Yahoo, AOL, Ask Jeeves, etc. One will emerge as your favorite perhaps, like how we all use Google even though Bing probably isn‚Äôt that bad anymore (I wouldn‚Äôt know‚Ä¶).1

Point is: it‚Äôs a race to the bottom, the customer is fickle. They know this, which is why they keep releasing new stuff every 6 months.

Point is: as you build your LLM application, your customer will be divinely discontent with you. This is nothing knew, it‚Äôs just the age of software development.

Expectations of what software can do are rising. Those expectations are becoming indiscernible from the magic that software is becoming.

  1. Edge is better than Chrome for now in LLM usage!‚Ü©Ô∏é

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: Holiday Demand Forecasting using XGBoost
item.description:
How DoorDash Improves Holiday Predictions via Cascade ML Approach - DoorDash Engineering Blog

  1. Transform your raw data, removing spikes
  2. Fit a trend like to the transformed data
  3. Predict tomorrow using transformed predicfions
  4. reverse The transformation to get expected numbers.

It‚Äôs kinda of the principle behind differencing: it‚Äôs making more stationary a time series.

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: This drug is habit forming
item.description:
Sometimes they tell you that at the pharmacy: ‚Äúthis drug is habit forming‚Äù. Or, the saline nasal spray bottle thing I tried once, ‚Äúthis spray is refreshing, but not habit forming.‚Äù Oh, how nice.

Why doesn‚Äôt everything have this distinction? Driving in the car: non habit forming. Eating a bag of goldfish when I‚Äôm noodling on a work problem: def habit forming.

One time, someone put a candy jar with skittles right beside my desk. It was for the whole floor, but my consumption was certainly not a pro-rata share. Buggy code? Gimme some skittles. Habit formed.

Social media? Someone likes your post? Habit formed.

Why don‚Äôt they warn that social media is one of the most addictive digital things we do? That we‚Äôve just accepted as a society?

It took until 1964 before the surgeon general announced smoking caused cancer. The first cigarette machine was invented in 1881 by Albert Bonsack. That‚Äôs +80 years, not to mention it was popular for much longer before that.

So yes, society can get it wrong for many years before they change course and do the more healthful thing.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: The Matrix: Social Media‚Äôs Influence on Human Interaction
item.description:
‚ÄúHave you ever been alone in a crowded room?‚Äù - Dark Blue, Jack‚Äôs Mannequin

I know kung fu - Neo, ‚ÄúThe Matrix‚Äù

What do these to quotes have in common? Social Media.

Everyone on social media is downloading something. They do it because they want to learn kung fu. And while they‚Äôre not on social media, other people are getting the download even more.

Something strange happens once you start spending 3+ hours on social a day. You start to see what‚Äôs actually going on. You start getting the cross-internet jokes. And once you do, you feel alone in a crowded room: you get the jokes that nobody else in your family gets. (Presumably because they have lives not on social media.)

Detach from social (A Knife to a Gun Fight: Why I‚Äôm off Social Media) and you start to see something else: when you‚Äôre not on your phone at a party, you start to see just how much everyone is on social. Checking their SMS, their posts, etc. That‚Äôs when you really feel alone in a crowded room.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: A Knife to a Gun Fight: Why I‚Äôm off Social Media
item.description:
Tim Ferris describes why he doesn‚Äôt have social media on his phone:

I recently deleted social media from my phone 14 days ago. I had been using Instagram until April when I quit and migrated to Twitter the rest of the year. I recently realized within days how much better I felt without social media. Happier. Legitimately happier.

And why? What did I get out of it? I wasn‚Äôt growing closer to friends. That‚Äôs what texting and calling and spending time in person does. But I‚Äôd argue even texting doesn‚Äôt really strengthen a relationship because it‚Äôs so hard to properly interpret emotions and cues via text: you interpret them how you read those texts. You interpret it according to your emotional state, not the sender‚Äôs.

Phone provides vocal emotional cues. Body language another set of emotional cues. I can get probably 70% of this out from FaceTime or Zoom. But being in person is what we‚Äôre meant for.

This is why we strengthen relationships locally, and fail to continue ones from high school or our previous job.

So what was I doing on social media? Watching clips of either strangers I don‚Äôt care about or college associates I friended (once lived locally with) that I no longer talk to.

So what‚Äôs the knife you‚Äôre bringing to the gun fight? When at YouTube I heard the CEO praise a team for increasing ‚Äúseconds watched‚Äù by 15% by reducing the lag of the swipes between YouTube shorts (TikTok clone). The lag reduction was in the milliseconds. Meaning: they made the slot machine more addictive.

Your attention is being bought and manipulated by the shareholders of these companies.

They A/B test everything. This isn‚Äôt morally wrong. It‚Äôs actually quite human: we all A/B test everything every day. A joke here. A smile there. We put out feelers and see if we get a reaction. Don‚Äôt believe me? Ask my kid why he keeps throwing things in the toilet!

Billions of dollars and the brightest minds on earth are working at FAANG. Why? They need to provide for their families and academics doesn‚Äôt pay. Non-profits don‚Äôt pay. This isn‚Äôt immoral, it just is. There are very good people working there: honest, moral people. Some of the best I‚Äôve seen in the industry. But when you get paid to maximize swipes, you maximize swipes. It‚Äôs just human nature. And some of them buy into the odd notions of ‚Äúsnackable content‚Äù, as if swiping for 30 minutes while on the toilet is what anyone wakes up excited to do. Keep on snacking‚Ä¶

Social media and Netflix provide a ton of value to the world in my opinion. I can use them to call anyone I want, raise money for a cause, or get likes on a cute pic of my cat (I don‚Äôt have a cat). I do see the value.

But the costs for me have outweighed the value.

I do miss laughing about some random Reel. There‚Äôs nothing that can get you laughing faster than a 10 second clip paired with the right cuts and music and everything. The right meme just nails it in a way nothing else can. I miss seeing memes from my friends. But when all I do is send memes to these friends, is that a friendship?

Since being off social media I feel like my senses have grown. I now find my kids a lot funnier, my wife funnier, and I‚Äôm able to make heavy situations lighter much easier.

There‚Äôs a quote in Dune that‚Äôs something like ‚ÄúIf you rely only on your eyes, your other senses weaken‚Äù. I‚Äôd argue my other relationships had weakened too. Time to leave the fight. I was losing.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: AI won‚Äôt replace us. We‚Äôll always create.
item.description:
I recently got back into writing some poems. The Dove (Forevermore) was fun to write. After the fact, I tried getting ChatGPT to create something similar. I only tried once before declaring victory.

Why is this poem meaningful to me? Because it has my soul in it. It‚Äôs the summation of my experience as a parent. Should you find it interesting, perhaps that‚Äôs why.

Reading The Best of Edgar Allen Poe recently I‚Äôm amazed (besides how depressing he is) at how excellent a writer he is. He peers into the mind and soul and extricates anything interesting. It‚Äôs interesting because a human wrote it.

Do we still paint, even if a camera can take a picture? Do we still ride bikes and horses even with cars and things? Do we still read even though we have TV and movies?

Words. Creative expression. They will always be interesting to us. Humans are interesting to us. Stories. Social acceptance is a fundamental human need. We desire connection. We‚Äôll like reading something because a human wrote it.

But what about that guy I heard about who makes a ton of money using ChatGPT to create fake digital books on Amazon. People don‚Äôt know it‚Äôs AI-written. Digital GenAI images now are insanely accurate - it‚Äôs only 2024. It‚Äôs very possible great AI art will inspire us more than non-AI art (whatever that means because everyone uses photoshop anyway).

I‚Äôm not saying we won‚Äôt find value in AI art (creative writing, digital, video, etc.). We will. It‚Äôs clear we‚Äôll have a really hard time knowing what‚Äôs human vs not.

But I am saying that creativity will never disappear. We‚Äôre always going to be interested in creating - even if machines can do it better. Machines can beat us at Go and StarCraft (AI Robots are mastering tasks faster than humans), but we‚Äôll still play. Because what else will there be to do?

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: What startups and musicians have in common
item.description:
I was reminded of a video I watched a while back on YouTube. It was a great documentary about these new artists and their debate about whether to sign a record label (there‚Äôs a recent trend to selling music as an independent artist).

I forget all the details, but there are some roughly insane trends that are generally interesting as I recall:

  • new record labels are for $500k give or take. This is so the artist can invest a year into their music and get an album out, pay for production, etc.
  • many artists at that early stage aren‚Äôt financially literate and end up wasting the (they‚Äôre musicians, not bankers)
  • Some have to pay back the money
  • Up to 85% of the streaming royalties are owed to the label (started when streaming became a thing)
  • Labels also take a large portion of touring revenues now (something that wasn‚Äôt common 10 years ago)

Why is this similar to tech startups? Lots.

Musicians have to find product market fit. They need to find their customers. Their monthly listeners.

They need to keep them coming back.

They need to differentiate.

Those who are customer focused and build a following are those who succeed. (Money in the bank and relying too much on the label can cripple you)

The Musicians in Town

I remember hanging out with some new artists while I was running my startup (we both used the same videographer). I couldn‚Äôt help but notice how similar the dynamics were. The founders. The first hires (replacements). The convos about who gets what. It‚Äôs all very fascinating.

Not much else to say.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: The future wave of AI hype
item.description:
Reading about Airplane‚Äôs failure per OnlyCFO. A few notable quotes:

Airplane‚Äôs shutdown and future shutdowns like this will have negative consequences for many early stage companies. For many years buyers of these tools haven‚Äôt had to deal with a tool being abruptly killed. It only takes this happening once for you to really second guess purchasing a startup tool that is mission critical, deeply integrated, or would take a long time to replace.

Also:

This chart is misleading for a few reasons:

  1. What‚Äôs the denominator?
  2. What‚Äôs the denominator‚Ä¶
  3. Denomi‚Ä¶

As Carta grows, their user base grows, their churn rate grows.

I‚Äôm also concerned for Carta‚Äôs investors. If they‚Äôve got this many churning users, I‚Äôd really like to know the denominator.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: The Dream State of Software
item.description:
I returned from vacation yesterday and tried running my code. It didn‚Äôt work. I looked at code I had written, it had my imports correctly and all - why wasn‚Äôt it running?

The file it was importing didn‚Äôt exist.

I thought I created that. I swear I made it. My coworker remarked, ‚Äúoh so you set up all the scafffolding but didn‚Äôt write the actual code?‚Äù I was in disbelief. maybe it was deleted by accident or stashed on another branch. But the git log shows all: the imported file never existed.

In Dune, Paul Atriedes has many visions and the author uses this feature to skip the book ahead three years. Paul wakes up one morning and doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs past or future. It‚Äôs all one in his mind.

So it is with software. It gets created in the mind near instantly. Coding is a burden, the journey of many failures and design choices to enable the simple vision of the mind.

Perhaps Gen AI can help us dream software faster. I look forward to when my dreams are realities, and not the rude awakening I still have coding to do.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:
